anchoring_bias.name: Anchoring Bias
anchoring_bias.description: The tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information encountered when making decisions.
anchoring_bias.example: A person thinks a $1000 jacket is cheap after seeing one priced at $5000.

confirmation_bias.name: Confirmation Bias
confirmation_bias.description: Favoring information that confirms preexisting beliefs or values.
confirmation_bias.example: Reading only news that supports one's political opinion.

availability_heuristic.name: Availability Heuristic
availability_heuristic.description: Overestimating the importance of information that is easily recalled.
availability_heuristic.example: Fearing plane crashes more than car accidents due to media coverage.

bandwagon_effect.name: Bandwagon Effect
bandwagon_effect.description: Adopting beliefs or behaviors because many other people do.
bandwagon_effect.example: Buying a trending product because everyone else does.

status_quo_bias.name: Status Quo Bias
status_quo_bias.description: Preferring things to stay the same rather than change.
status_quo_bias.example: Keeping an old subscription instead of switching to a better one.

self_serving_bias.name: Self-Serving Bias
self_serving_bias.description: Attributing success to personal skill and failure to external factors.
self_serving_bias.example: Blaming the weather for losing a tennis match but taking credit for wins.

fundamental_attribution_error.name: Fundamental Attribution Error
fundamental_attribution_error.description: Overemphasizing personal traits while underestimating situational factors when judging others.
fundamental_attribution_error.example: Assuming someone is lazy because they are late, without knowing the context.

halo_effect.name: Halo Effect
halo_effect.description: Letting one positive trait influence overall perception.
halo_effect.example: Thinking an attractive person is also intelligent and kind.

horn_effect.name: Horn Effect
horn_effect.description: Letting one negative trait influence overall judgment.
horn_effect.example: Disliking someone entirely because of a single rude remark.

in_group_bias.name: In-group Bias
in_group_bias.description: Favoring members of one's own group over outsiders.
in_group_bias.example: Hiring someone from the same university instead of a more qualified candidate.

optimism_bias.name: Optimism Bias
optimism_bias.description: Believing that you are less likely to experience negative events.
optimism_bias.example: Underestimating the chance of getting sick.

pessimism_bias.name: Pessimism Bias
pessimism_bias.description: Overestimating the likelihood of negative outcomes.
pessimism_bias.example: Believing a project will fail despite strong preparation.

negativity_bias.name: Negativity Bias
negativity_bias.description: Giving more weight to negative experiences than positive ones.
negativity_bias.example: Focusing on one bad review among dozens of good ones.

recency_bias.name: Recency Bias
recency_bias.description: Giving greater importance to the most recent information.
recency_bias.example: Thinking a stock will keep rising because it has risen recently.

sunk_cost_fallacy.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
sunk_cost_fallacy.description: Continuing an endeavor because of previously invested resources.
sunk_cost_fallacy.example: Finishing a bad movie because you already paid for the ticket.

overconfidence_bias.name: Overconfidence Bias
overconfidence_bias.description: Overestimating one's own abilities or knowledge.
overconfidence_bias.example: Believing one drives better than most people.

dunning_kruger_effect.name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
dunning_kruger_effect.description: People with low ability at a task overestimate their ability.
dunning_kruger_effect.example: A novice believing they can perform like an expert.

false_consensus_effect.name: False Consensus Effect
false_consensus_effect.description: Overestimating how much others share your beliefs or behaviors.
false_consensus_effect.example: Assuming everyone enjoys the same type of movies.

survivorship_bias.name: Survivorship Bias
survivorship_bias.description: Focusing on successes while ignoring failures.
survivorship_bias.example: Studying successful entrepreneurs without examining those who failed.

illusion_of_control.name: Illusion of Control
illusion_of_control.description: Believing you can control or influence outcomes that you cannot.
illusion_of_control.example: Believing your lucky charm affects an exam result.

just_world_hypothesis.name: Just-World Hypothesis
just_world_hypothesis.description: Believing the world is fair and people get what they deserve.
just_world_hypothesis.example: Assuming poor people must have made bad choices.
